text: [music playing]

SPORTS ANNOUNCER:
And he's tasting some
of the power of Carl Frampton.

LEO SANTA CRUZ: Yeah, it
was very tough, you know,

it was very hard, you
know, when I first
found out that he had cancer.

You know, I cried, and-- and I
imagined myself like, you know,
suffering.

He was suffering
from cancer, and he

wasn't able to be
with me, pushing

me, and doing all those
things that I was used to.

JOSE SANTA CRUZ
(THROUGH INTERPRETER):

The toughest part really
right now, physically,

is the chemotherapy,
because it comes
with a lot of side effects.
It really truly is bothersome.

At the moment, I'm suffering
from having a sullen stomach,

and my feet feel like they're
on fire, but to this day

I have not been
afraid of the cancer.

LEO SANTA CRUZ: I
feel pretty confident,
you know, on my training.

And with having my
dad here with me,

he's been the whole time
training me and motivating me.

And so they've been
pushing me to my limit,
and I think I feel strong.
I feel fast.

Ah-- my legs feel
good and everything.

SPORTS ANNOUNCER: Oh, good
counter [inaudible] Santa Cruz,
and he catches him with a 1-2.

LEO SANTA CRUZ: I vision myself
with my family, you know, right

there after the fight,
the judge, you know,

raising my hand, getting my
belt back, and everybody happy,

screaming, you know,
putting their hands up

JOSE SANTA CRUZ (THROUGH
INTERPRETER): For this fight,

I want to make a
promise to his audience,

that he's not only going to beat
him, he's gonna beat him down.
